clusters.title: Teen who murdered doctor Ash Gordon jailed for at least 12 years
clusters.neutral_headline: Teenager Sentenced for Murder of Melbourne Doctor
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, 9News, ABC Just In

items.title: Teen who murdered doctor Ash Gordon jailed for at least 12 years
items.standfirst: A teenage boy who fatally stabbed a Melbourne doctor he had just burgled has been sentenced to 17 years’ jail. With time already served, he will be eligible for release in 2036.
items.content: A teenage boy who fatally stabbed a Melbourne doctor he had just burgled has been sentenced to 17 years’ jail. With time already served, he will be eligible for release in 2036.

items.title: Teen sentenced over murder of beloved GP in Melbourne
items.standfirst: The doctor was left to die on the ground after being stabbed six times.
items.content: A teen who murdered a beloved Melbourne GP has been jailed for 17 years for brutally stabbing an unarmed man.The boy, now 18, looked straight ahead as Victorian Supreme Court Justice Amanda Fox handed down his sentence this morning.A jury found he murdered doctor Ashley Gordon near his Doncaster home in Melbourne's north-east early on January 13, 2024.READ MORE: Hundreds of jobs on the line as caravan maker collapsesThe teen and a friend broke into the house about 4am, stealing shoes, headphones, laptops, a wallet and silver necklaces.They went back to a nearby house party before returning to Gordon's house, planning to steal the Mercedes-Benz that was parked in the garage.Gordon caught them as they tried to break in a second time, chasing the teens onto the street and then following them in his car.READ MORE: Trump gives green light to release MRI resultsHe got out of the vehicle once they reached a nearby street and the doctor tried to restrain the then-16-year-old, telling him the police were on their way.But the boy pulled out a knife and stabbed Gordon six times before leaving him to die on the ground.Justice Fox described the murder as a brutal attack against an unarmed man as she sentenced the teen to 17 years' jail.READ MORE: Australia's happiest generation of workers revealedHe will be eligible for parole after 12 years.Gordon's family and friends let out a gasp and then cried as the sentence was handed down.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Man sentenced to 17 years in jail for murder of Melbourne doctor
items.standfirst: Ashley Gordon grew up in the Victorian coal mining town of Morwell and went on to become a doctor before he was murdered.
items.content: Ashley Gordon grew up in the Victorian coal mining town of Morwell and went on to become a doctor before he was murdered.

ai_summary: A teenager was sentenced for murdering a Melbourne doctor.
The doctor was stabbed six times.
The teen was sentenced to 17 years in jail.
The doctor was murdered after a burglary.
The teen will be eligible for release in 2036.

clusters.title: Man dies, another injured in retaining wall collapse in Brisbane
clusters.neutral_headline: One Dead, Another Injured in Brisbane Wall Collapse
bullet_summary: Reported by 9News, The Age, ABC News Australia

items.title: Man dies, another injured in retaining wall collapse in Brisbane
items.standfirst: Queensland Ambulance Service confirmed two patients are being treated for significant injuries, including one patient who is entrapped after a retaining wall collapsed on Boundary Street in Brisbane's West End.
items.content: A man has died and another has been injured after a retaining wall collapsed in Brisbane's West End this morning. Queensland Ambulance Service confirmed two patients suffered significant injuries when a retaining wall collapsed on Boundary Street in the inner -southern suburb just before 8.30am.A 45-year-old man was in a life-threatening condition when paramedics arrived and died at the scene. A 19-year-old man was also injured and has been taken to the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital in a stable condition after a "prolonged extrication" that took more than an hour.The younger man was trapped from the waist down and was assisted by other workers on the scene who helped move rubble to allow paramedics to reach him. Police are also on the scene and have described it as a workplace incident.Workplace Health and Safety will investigate. Boundary Street is currently closed between Melbourne Street and Edmondstone Street and motorists are advised to avoid the area.More to come.

clusters.title: Man injured in mystery Sydney shooting refusing to cooperate with police

bullet_summary: The man showed up to a hospital in south-west Sydney with a gunshout wound to his leg

items.title: Man injured in mystery Sydney shooting refusing to cooperate with police
items.standfirst: The man showed up to a hospital in south-west Sydney with a gunshout wound to his leg.
items.content: Investigations into a suspected shooting in Sydney's south-west are being hampered by the victim's unwillingness to cooperate with police.Police were called to Fairfield Hospital late last night after a 43-year-old man arrived with a gunshot wound to his leg.It is not known where the shooting took place, or who the perpetrator may have been.READ MORE: Man dies, another injured in retaining wall collapse in Brisbane9News understands the victim has not been cooperative with police in presenting the circumstances of the shooting.The man was then transferred to another hospital for treatment.Police are investigating the incident, and have seized the car that the man was taken to hospital in for forensic examination.A crime scene has not formally been declared, and police are urging anyone with information on the incident to call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. items.title: Greek astronomy is ancient; this Wiradjuri knowledge is far older
items.standfirst: All 88 internationally recognised constellations have European origins. But First Nations astronomy tells older, beautiful stories that contain invaluable lessons and knowledge.
items.content: All 88 internationally recognised constellations have European origins. But First Nations astronomy tells older, beautiful stories that contain invaluable lessons and knowledge.

ai_summary: All international constellations have European origins.
First Nations astronomy offers older, rich stories.
These stories contain valuable lessons and knowledge.
Wiradjuri knowledge is significantly older.
Greek astronomy is considered ancient.

clusters.title: More than 1,160 dead after extreme flooding across Asia
clusters.neutral_headline: Extreme Flooding Across Asia Claims Over 1,160 Lives

items.title: More than 1,160 dead after extreme flooding across Asia
items.standfirst: Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka are reeling from flooding that has killed hundreds in each country and destroyed communities.
items.content: Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka are reeling from flooding that has killed hundreds in each country and destroyed communities.

ai_summary: Flooding has caused over 1,160 deaths across Asia.
Indonesia, Thailand, and Sri Lanka are severely affected.
Hundreds of deaths occurred in each of these countries.
Communities have been destroyed by the floods.
The flooding is considered extreme.

clusters.title: Princess's popularity spurs calls to ditch male-only succession in Japan
clusters.neutral_headline: Princess's Popularity Fuels Succession Debate in Japan

items.title: Princess's popularity spurs calls to ditch male-only succession in Japan
items.standfirst: Historically, Japan has had numerous women monarchs. But current laws prevent the emperor's daughter from succeeding him — and politicians, including the prime minister, support the status quo.
items.content: Historically, Japan has had numerous women monarchs. But current laws prevent the emperor's daughter from succeeding him — and politicians, including the prime minister, support the status quo.

ai_summary: The Princess's popularity is driving calls for change.
Current laws prevent the Emperor's daughter from succeeding.
Historically, Japan had numerous female monarchs.
Politicians, including the Prime Minister, support the status quo.
The debate concerns male-only succession.

clusters.title: Japanese encephalitis virus detected in Victoria
clusters.neutral_headline: Japanese Encephalitis Virus Detected in Victoria

items.title: Japanese encephalitis virus detected in Victoria
items.standfirst: The first detection of Japanese encephalitis virus for the summer has been made in a rural Victorian city.
items.content: The first detection of Japanese encephalitis virus for the summer has been made in a rural Victorian city.

ai_summary: Japanese encephalitis virus was detected in Victoria.
This is the first detection for the summer season.
The detection occurred in a rural Victorian city.
The virus is a health concern.
The detection marks the start of summer surveillance.

clusters.title: Hegseth authorised drug boat strike criticised by Trump
clusters.neutral_headline: US Defense Secretary Criticized for Drug Boat Strike

items.title: Hegseth authorised drug boat strike criticised by Trump
items.standfirst: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth authorised an admiral to conduct multiple strikes that killed 11 people on a vessel from Venezuela allegedly carrying illegal narcotics in September.
items.content: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth authorised an admiral to conduct multiple strikes that killed 11 people on a vessel from Venezuela allegedly carrying illegal narcotics in September.

ai_summary: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth authorized a strike.
The strike killed eleven people on a Venezuelan vessel.
The vessel was allegedly carrying illegal narcotics.
The strike occurred in September.
The authorization is drawing criticism.

clusters.title: Filmmaker reveals eyewitness saw police allegedly murder Aboriginal clan leader
clusters.neutral_headline: Filmmaker Reveals Alleged Police Murder of Aboriginal Leader
bullet_summary: Acclaimed filmmaker George Gittoes has revealed a former NT police officer told him he witnessed his colleagues taking a Yolŋu clan leader out to shoot him and dump his body in Darwin Harbour in 1934

items.title: Filmmaker reveals eyewitness saw police allegedly murder Aboriginal clan leader
items.standfirst: Acclaimed filmmaker George Gittoes has revealed a former NT police officer told him he witnessed his colleagues taking a Yolŋu clan leader out to shoot him and dump his body in Darwin Harbour in 1934.
items.content: Acclaimed filmmaker George Gittoes has revealed a former NT police officer told him he witnessed his colleagues taking a Yolŋu clan leader out to shoot him and dump his body in Darwin Harbour in 1934.

ai_summary: A filmmaker revealed an eyewitness account.
The eyewitness saw police allegedly murder a leader.
The incident occurred in 1934 in Darwin Harbour.
The victim was a Yolŋu clan leader.
The former NT police officer shared the account.

clusters.title: 'I never wanted speech therapy': Deaf man incensed by NDIS recommendation
clusters.neutral_headline: Deaf Man Criticizes NDIS Recommendation for Speech Therapy

items.title: 'I never wanted speech therapy': Deaf man incensed by NDIS recommendation
items.standfirst: Disability advocates say cuts to Deaf participants' NDIS funding is a "systemic" problem that reflects a belief that Deafness can be "fixed".
items.content: Disability advocates say cuts to Deaf participants' NDIS funding is a "systemic" problem that reflects a belief that Deafness can be "fixed".

ai_summary: A Deaf man is incensed by an NDIS recommendation.
Disability advocates cite a "systemic" problem.
The problem reflects a belief that Deafness can be "fixed".
Cuts to Deaf participants' funding are a concern.
The man never wanted speech therapy.

clusters.title: WHO declares obesity a disease, says Ozempic can be used to treat it
clusters.neutral_headline: WHO Declares Obesity a Disease, Recommends Ozempic

items.title: WHO declares obesity a disease, says Ozempic can be used to treat it
items.standfirst: Ozempic-style medications have been recommended as long-term treatments for obesity under new guidelines released by the World Health Organization.
items.content: Ozempic-style medications have been recommended as long-term treatments for obesity under new guidelines released by the World Health Organization.

ai_summary: The WHO declared obesity a disease.
Ozempic-style medications are recommended.
These medications are for long-term obesity treatment.
New guidelines were released by the WHO.
The recommendations are for obesity management.
